comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Fascinating! I thought Menangle, but it is not. Mr Hall must have been on another bridge. Or ship. Hmmm ...

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] This one's a challenge. I thought perhaps it was Meadowbank on the Parramatta River, but this bridge isn't long enough. Will tag you again if we crack it!
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 47201412@N02
32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] BRILLIANT ! btw date of photo? 1890s? Who would have thought Wellington? The railway arrived in 1880. And this bridge is still used - "The town is served by twice a day the daily Countrylink XPT service which runs between Sydney and Dubbo and return. The train stops heading to Dubbo at 12:58pm and heading to Sydney at 2:47pm." [from Wikipedia] GoogleMapsStreetView - looking a bit rusty after 133 years.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] So Mr Hall had a Grand Day Out in Wellington with his camera - there may be more unidentified photos of the town in the series.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Another earlier view of the bridge when just completed 1883 (? - see vignetting) - investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp...

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Fantastic! Thanks for the identification and all the fabulous links! This link says the bridge was built in 1881. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] I hope that more images of the town come out from our collection - I would say Hall was travelling to photograph livestock at one of the farms out west. In his time he was best known as probably the best livestock photographer around, a bit of a change from regattas :)
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] Yes 1881 for the bridge date is good. It was tested on 25/1/1881 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/70952247 . I had forgotten about Mr Hall's connection with livestock too. That makes sense. Here is the slightly older wooden truss road bridge he was standing on to take the photo - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=63326

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Thanks Beachcomber, it is great to have a pic of the old bridge he was standing on, such a complete picture.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons
